name: Bembridge and Culver Downs trail, Isle of Wight

ai.summary: A demanding 24-kilometre coastal ridge hike on the Isle of Wight, following Bembridge and Culver Downs with expansive sea views, chalk uplands, and rugged trails.
ai.terrain_summary: The route traverses chalk downland and exposed ridges with steep ascents and descents, uneven chalk tracks, and some gravel sections. Expect windy, open sections near the coast and cliff-top portions; surfaces can be loose and weather can change quickly, so navigation and steady footing are essential.
ai.safety_notes: Stay on marked paths and away from unstable cliff edges on Bembridge and Culver Downs. Check the weather forecast and be prepared for sudden wind shifts and rain. Carry a map and compass or GPS, and a fully charged phone. Bring enough water and snacks, wear sturdy boots, and plan for a long day due to the 24 km distance. In poor conditions or limited daylight, shorten or split the hike. Keep dogs on a leash where required and watch for signage near sensitive cliff areas.
recommended_gear: Weather-appropriate layers (base layer, insulation, waterproof shell)
Water and high-energy snacks (at least 2–3 litres of water)
Map and compass or GPS device (plus charged phone with offline maps)
Lightweight rain gear and a compact emergency kit
Small first aid kit and any personal medications
Walking poles (optional but helpful on exposed ridges)
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly March to October) for drier trails and clearer views; winter hikes are possible but more exposed and require extra caution and daylight planning.
